Brian Zhang [this website is still a wip]

Hey there! I'm a Software Engineering student at the University of Waterloo. My research interests lie broadly in the intersection of self-driving, generative models, and computer vision. At this stage of my career, I'm also trying to explore and branch out into other areas. Outside of school and work, I like to play piano, play chess, and explore new places.

Experience

May 2025 - Aug 2025

I am an autopilot machine learning intern on the Fleet Learning team at Tesla, working on end-to-end vision foundation models for Full Self-Driving, under Charles Qi.

Jan 2025 - Apr 2025

Back at Waabi, researching generative models for adversarial traffic scenario generation under Raquel Urtasun.

May 2024 - Present

I was a visiting researcher at the Deep Structured Learning Lab at the University of British Columbia, where I worked on flow and diffusion based generative models for motion prediction, under Renjie Liao. I worked in person at UBC during summer 2024, and I'm currently continuing to work remote part-time, researching video generation models in this lab.

May 2024 - Aug 2024

I was a machine learning engineer intern at Kolena, where I worked with LLMs and RAG.

Sept 2023 - Dec 2023

I was an ML research intern at Waabi, where I worked on modelling realsitic traffic agents for closed-loop simulation under Raquel Urtasun.

Jan 2023 - Apr 2023

I was a software developer intern at CareGuide, where I built and deployed a scammer detection system from scratch.

May 2022 - Aug 2022

I was a backend software developer intern for OANDA, where I worked on user management and authentication servies for the ForEx trading platform.

Publications

TrajFlow: Multi-modal Motion Prediction via Flow Matching

Under review at IROS

Qi Yan, Brian Zhang, Yutong Zhang, Daniel Yang, Joshua White, Di Chen, Jiachao Liu, Langechuan Liu, Binnan Zhuang, Shaoshuai Shi, Renjie Liao

We introduce TrajFlow, a novel flow matching-based motion prediction framework that addresses the scalability and efficiency challenges of existing generative trajectory prediction methods. Experiments on the large-scale Waymo Open Motion Dataset demonstrate that TrajFlow achieves state-of-the-art performance across various key metrics.
